title: Sexual abuse rife in Aboriginal communities
contributor: Tanya Nolan (Reporter); The Abc is currently reviewing the provision of full online transcripts for The World Today program. We apologise for any inconvenience. In order to assist the users of our site, the Abc is providing audio-on-demand files and a summary of each current affairs report. Previous transcripts are still available through the online archives.As a State Government inquiry into violence in Aboriginal communities gets underway in Perth today there's disturbing new information about the nationwide problem. Despite numerous inquiries and millions of dollars spent addressing the issue, the latest evidence suggests that the situation remains horrific and that sexual abuse in particular is causing Aboriginal culture to implode.Recent research has found that Aboriginal women are nearly 50 times more likely to be subjected to family violence than other Australians and that more than three quarters of the women in the Aboriginal population have suffered sexual abuse.Related LinksNew South Wales Aboriginal Justice Advisory CouncilAtsic

title: NRMA president found guilty of breaking corporate law
contributor: Simon Santow (Reporter); Corporate governance has been one of the most talked about issues globally over the last few weeks. Overseas, the shonky accounting practices of Worldcom and Andersens have hit the headlines, while at home, shareholders and the business community have been shocked by revelations of corporate misconduct at Hih and Onetel.Now a decision in the New South Wales Supreme Court this morning has further dented the image of company directors.Nrma president Nicholas Whitlam has been found to have breached the corporations law at the motoring giant's annual general meeting four years ago.The charges arose out of Mister Whitlam's refusal to sign 4,000 proxy votes assigned to him. The votes were cast against a proposal to dramatically increase directors' fees.A penalty of as much as $200,000 and disqualification from serving as a company director could be imposed against Nicholas Whitlam, when the judge makes a determination next week.Editor's Note

This most exotic city from the Kingdom of Morocco was filmed entirely in the Burbank studios in Hollywood, recreated there.But travelling in the real Morocco can be an adventure. title: Drought slices farm income by 60 per cent
contributor: Ian Henderson (Reporter); And there's a lot of bad memories, not only amongst the Ansett people of the way they've experienced things, but a lot of bad memories from the farming and grazing community of the behaviour of banks and the way they foreclosed on people who owed money during the 1980's and the 90's.Today, the National Party leader and Deputy Prime Minister, John Anderson, a man of the land himself, is meeting with the banks, urging them to take it easy on struggling drought-affected farmers this time around.While that meeting's going on in Sydney, there are new official figures out, showing just how severely farmers are being affected financially by the current conditions. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (Abare) says the average cash income will fall this year to just $43,000, down from almost $111,000 in 2001-02.I'm joined in The World Today studio by our Economics Correspondent, Ian Henderson...Ian, now this latest Abare report is based on a survey of farmers in both the broad acre and dairy industries… in general terms, actually how badly are these farmers being hit by the drought?Ian Henderson
